awd_titl_txt: Experimental validation of molecular simulation of water transport across zeolite membranes of nanoscale-thickness
awd_abstract_narration:
Transport of a fluid in porous media is relevant to extraction of oil from the subsurface, contaminant transport in groundwater, sequestration of carbon dioxide in underground reservoirs, and desalination of seawater through a reverse osmosis membrane to produce drinking water. The porous media offers a resistance to the transport of mass. Differences in resistance between chemical species allow for separation: one component may be unimpeded or even accelerated, while another is impeded. For example, the reverse osmosis membrane is designed to transport water quite efficiently but transport salt quite inefficiently, leading to the production of purified drinking water. To optimize design, engineering transport models of flow through porous media generally treat the system using macroscopic length scales and average resistances, but generally neglect both spatial variations and specific fluid-surface interactions on the molecular scale. Molecular-scale interactions become quite pronounced when a fluid molecule is confined in a pore that is of similar molecular dimension. Models that account for molecular interactions incorporate forcefields, but have not adequately predicted experimental observations. This project will perform an experimental validation of molecular-level transport through a porous material with strong fluid-pore interactions, and for the first time, there will be a one-to-one length scale correspondence between the experimental and theoretical studies which will probe discrepancies. 

In this project, desalination of seawater through a zeolite membrane is the probe system, due to strong water-zeolite electrostatic interactions that are enhanced upon confinement in sub-nanometer (~0.56 nm) pores. MFI zeolites with varying aluminum composition and thickness (varying from nano- to micro-scale) will be experimentally synthesized and characterized, then transferred onto a support surface to create membranes for transport measurements in a custom-built experimental apparatus. MD simulations will be simultaneously performed for the same zeolites with varying forcefields.  The aluminum content will be varied in both techniques to alter the water-zeolite interaction. The experimentally validated molecular models will provide fundamental understanding of water interaction in confined pores, and assist in the development of predictive modeling of thermodynamic properties and transport behavior of water in nano-porous materials. The project includes several outreach components, including undergraduate research projects that target under-represented minorities, a workshop for middle school female students, and a short course in computational methods for undergraduates at Syracuse University.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Water crisis is affecting over a billion people worldwide who lack access to clean drinking water. Desalination is used to convert seawater to drinking water, but is an energy intensive process. A very widely used desalination method is reverse osmosis, where seawater is pumped across a membrane to separate out the salt. However, current membranes are thick in size requiring large amount of pumping energy to push the water through. Thus, the development of efficient membranes is critical for reducing desalination energy costs. An ideal membrane should be (1) extremely thin to minimize water pumping(energy) costs, and have (2) extremely small pores to achieve desalination by allowing the water molecules to pass through while preventing the larger-sized solvated salt ions. Zeolites are a good material as they naturally satisfy the #2 requirement of having extremely small pores; however, creating thin membranes over large areas is still a challenge. This project aims to address some of these challenges by studying the effect of zeolite membrane thickness on salt rejection, water-salt-zeolite interactions, and potential for creating thin zeolite membranes, which can efficiently desalinate saline water at lower energy costs, and thus address a key societal challenge present around the world.

In this project, zeolites are the focus of research as membrane material. Zeolites are crystalline aluminosilicates (bonded silicon, aluminum, and oxygen) with uniform sub-nanometer diameter pores (diameter ~ 0.56 nm), where the aluminum content can be varied to increase or decrease its affinity for water. Zeolites have been found to be a good candidate material for water desalination. ZSM-5 zeolite crystals were synthesized on the silicon substrate using microwave assisted heating method. Methodology was outlined and followed for the synthesis of zeolite crystals. XRD was conducted to show proof of zeolite growth. SEM imaging was done to measure crystal size and density of deposition on the surface. Strength of surface adhesion of zeolite crystals was tested via adhesive tape peeling as well as water jet impact. Zeolite coating on the surface degraded with such tests indicating that the zeolite crystals had low adhesion to the surface. Our work shows that, unlike literature publications, zeolite synthesis occurred in the solution followed by deposition on the surface, rather than growing directly from the surface. Growth of zeolite directly from the surface is needed towards creation of a membrane of desired thickness, so that strong adhesion occurs, and the underlying substrate can then be etched away to create a membrane.


Last Modified: 04/11/2024
Modified by: Shalabh C Maroo
